reviewText:
One of the best FF game out there.
The battle gameplay is simply amazing where you can exchange your MC through 14 available characters, and plus it also have a very unique style of battle gameplay where the battle system is no longer turn-based, but more dashing-button-kind-like gameplay.
The gameplay of the game is kinda different from the normal FF franchise game, where in this game you will need to complete missions in order to proceed, and after every mission, you will return to your country back.
Overall, the storyline is something that you want to anticipate in this game, where in my opinion is the darkest FF game that i ever played.

The only bad thing about this game is the 30fps locked. Thats all. The rest is amazing.

reviewText:
I played the PSP version and I considered this is the most favourite final fantasy game I ever played (I already play 8,9 and 10, also Dissidia, Dissidia 012).
Pros:
- Battle: 14 characters to control, action-based keep me from equiping no-encounter items. Previous Final Fantasy version make me get bored of the battle because of turn based.
- Story: Dark and a haunting ending.
- Graphics: I don't really care about other character, so the improved texture on class zero and some other main characters is enough. This is only a port game from PSP, I don't expect much with this price.

Cons:
- Hard to control. Really hard. I think Square Enix should've given players the ability to customize and bind key. That way I think most of us don't have controller but still can play the game easily with our habit of playing other games.
- No co-op feature. This feature really interesting in the PSP version. I greatly enjoyed it. But they take the feature out of this port, that's a huge dissapointment for me.
I think the camera is fine, maybe because I've got used to the camera of the PSP version.

For me, the big flaw of this game is the control thingy. If Square enix can fix this, I will be happy.

reviewText:
Played with a controller.
--------------------------------------------

First thing i have to say, is that i feel this game isn't the greatest looking. Even though it's a supposed HD remake, a lot of the textures look blurry, and the fact that a lot of characters mouths seem to move like GIFS (I from here on forth shall call the supporting characters GIF mouths!) isn't a pretty sight. However, main characters and characters more important to the story are well animated. The game is locked at 30 FPS, but i can understand that, being that the game has it's origin on the PSP. If you are able to look past these flaws, then it's a good game if you're in the possession of a controller.

SFX cutscenes look extremely good, and tell a deep story of war. The game doesn't shy away from deaths, and at the start, it was already sad. The game then continued into the main gameplay of missions, and is nicely packed with combat. There are a lot of characters to play with, each with their own destinct fighting style and weapons. I love the unique variety of weapons you can fight with. You have your standard arsenal of weapons, like spears, swords, staffs, scythes, but also uncommon weapons like cards or even the flute. It feels fresh, and every character, along with it's own personal weapon feels like a fresh way of fighting. One serious piece of advice though: set the audio to japanese. The English dub has horrible lip-syncing!

Since i've been playing the game with the controller, i can't say whether it'd be a recommended game to buy if you don't have one. Reading the reviews from others, i think the port might be slightly bad on the keyboard department. It doesn't allow you to map, you have 2 different ways of controller, pre-assigned by the game. If you can't get into either, then it could be problematic. However, with a controller, the game plays fine.

Is this game recommendable? yes, i think it is. Although it's not the prettiest game, the core mechanics are solid, and the story definitely grabs your attention. If you can look past it's flaws, it is definitely a must own, especially if you're a Final Fantasy fan.

My final rating would be a 7 / 10, a very solid game.

As always, a TL;DR:

Pros:
------------
- Fresh styles of fighting
- Excellent storytelling
- Very nice SFX cutscenes
- Solid core gameplay
- GIF mouths (THEY ARE HILARIOUS!)

Cons:
-------------
- Not the prettiest game
- Inconsistent texturing
- 30 FPS lock
- Only 2 ways of playing the game with keyboard, which aren't programmable
- Very controller based
- Not the best English dub
- GIF mouths (They're f****ing GIF MOUTHS!)
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's an amazing game. It's a definite must-have for me. Why?
Because it gives you a rollercoaster ride of feelings that look great and just is believable. The story is great, twists at every turn and oh, the ending, the ending. It's a heartbreaker this one. The characters are all different as well. Some are annoying (I'm looking at you, Machina), but all are distinct. Not only in their way of acting, but in their play styles as well. There's always someone you can play with. The sound is amazing, which is really to be expected from an FF-title, but this one has one of the most memorable yet. It just sticks.
While I'm not overly fond of the keymapping, especially during chapter six, it's not hard to learn and fairly easy to use. Your left-hand will just be working overtime.
The graphics are good, but sometimes the sound didn't coincide with the images, and the subtitles were half missing or going away to fast. Don't know if that has anything to do with my settings though. As for the subs themselves... they're, laughable at times. It's not the worst job I've ever seen, but certainly not the best one either.
The leveling up isn't always easy to do either, but replaying missions is a nice way I guess. I want S's on my reports damnit. My biggest issue (if you can call it that) is that I want more. More interactions, more classmoments. Moooooooorrree. There's never enough.
So yes, get it. Buy it. You will certainly not regret it.

reviewText:
>Boo hoo hoo, bad port, 30 FPS locked, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ controls, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ graphics...

It's really worth the money, and if you want to whine about a RPG's graphic options and commands without even having a glance at the story, well, go play another game. It's definitely worth it, despite all the whining.

However, I'd still recommand using a controller.

reviewText:
I think people need to stop ♥♥♥♥♥ing about the game, and more often than not people are giving this game a downvote due to 'WAH POOR GRAPHICS AND FRAMERATE WAAAAAAH'. Seriously, ♥♥♥♥ off.

This is a game that originally we were NOT supposed to get at all. This was originally a Japan exclusive for the PSP.

Now think, this is a PSP game, they upped the graphics a bit, but honestly, I don't care about the grapics too much if the story is good. I suggest people get their heads out of their arses and actually PLAY this for a good while to let the beginning of the story unfold.

Get over yourselves and your elitist standards and look at past games that were amazing.
Earthbound - It's 8-bit graphics, but an amazing game. People love it.
Chrono Trigger - Originally on the SNES as well, but it's an amazing game.
The original pokemon games - IN BLACK AND ♥♥♥♥ING WHITE PEOPLE.

Boo hoo, this game doesn't have the best resolution and graphics that is humanly possible. Get over it. Get over yourselves. Play this game. It's a lot darker than other Final Fantasy Titles, and it should not disappoint people who want a challange and great storyline.

To anyone who's not gonna buy this because it doesn't meet your 'visual standards', just get the hell out.

reviewText:
I am a Final Fantasy Veteran having played every game there is.
Those who vote negative for this game are just people who can't accept new things in their beloved Final Fantasy series. They want to play the same game over and over again just with different characters I guess.

In my opinion Final Fantasy Type 0 is a great game for everyone. It has a lot of playable character with each of them having individual playstyles which i really like. It features a dynamic battle system which is not as stiff as old ones and is pretty similar to Crisis Core(come on guys, turn based battles are good for PSX but not in 2015...that would look so stupid)
The story is a bit simple and filled with clichées but you have to consider that originally it was a PSP game, so don't expect too much there.
The port is not too bad either as you can simply adjust the screen size and turn the window into full mode.
The difficulty of the game can be set individually as well.

All in all a good and refreshing interpretation of Final Fantasy elements

reviewText:
If interested in the quality of the port, you can read it here:  ​Final Fantasy Type-0 port analysis

As for what I have seen, I think it's actually pretty good compared with the other Final Fantasy XIII (I have new hopes for Lightning Returns now). I mean, more HD quality, Speed Mode, Photo Mode, new direct access to commands, customize the camera, a proper launcher, etc. I think now they have worked but they still have to learnt. Like Keyboard/Mouse controles, they are bad, really use a controller.

Also I had no problem since the launch with the game and it keeps very well the 30 fps (yeah locked, but is not that bad for me). And the only thing is I'm not playing in 4K (The Anti-aliasing on Highest setting, very bad explained).

About the game, is a port from a PSP game, expect that. There are some textures really bad for the environment and you can't compare it with the others in details. But actually I think the gameplay is pretty interesting, I'm glad it has arrived to PC. Action combat, multiple characters and they are actually very different to play, world to explore, quest, a lot of lore, chocobos, magic, etc. as you expect from a Final Fantasy.

If you can't stand is psp game, if you think 30 fps is terrible, if you think is a bad port well we knew how it would be (I was expecting a worse port), forget about it. If you like Final Fantasy and want to play a great game, sure not the best in the series but pretty interesting, buy it. (Okey, I also just wanted that Square Enix release FFXV on PC too, but this game is better than I expected)

For the others reviews, I just think they are people who didn't expect what I said and that there is too much hate nowdays on the internet. Just see that reviews on the front page are actually good and compare what I said with the bad ones.

reviewText: Here's my verdict on FF Type 0: Fun to play, horrible story execution.  Also the characters show no personality because the story takes no time to focus on any of them.  When I unlocked the what if" scenario at the end and it showed them as normal students I actually found myself liking them as opposed to the blank slates they are generally presented as throughout the game.  At first I thought having each character from the get-go was a welcome change of pace for JRPGs but I quickly discovered that part of the character building in JRPGs comes from having them gradually join you in addition to having interactions with the rest of the characters.  So although I enjoyed the gameplay
date: I cannot recommend this game from a story perspective.  I find the best games balance the two out but it comes down to personal preference.  Is gameplay more important to you or is it story?"

reviewText:
I actually had hardly any technical issues with this title - apart from being sinfully locked to 30 it does a pretty good job of running well on PC. However everything else is terrible.
It's roots as a PSP title really shine through, from the awful camera control, to the low-poly models, the poor textures and the mouth-flapping cutscenes. Whatever strategy there is to the gameplay is lost in the mess of targetting and view changes.
Most unforgivably, the game has perhaps the worst opening chapters ever. It introduces places and characters willy-nilly without a care for narrative voice. A bunch of interchangable Nomura-haired characters prance along to a story that makes little to no sense yet.
Granted the story mght make more sense later - but not sson enough to hold my interest.

reviewText: Ignore the mixed reviews. This game is very fun, and I can recommend it to anyone who loves real time combat action that is fluid with the gameplay, and to anyone who loves a good story. This game is darker than the other FF titles, so be ready for that. I believe people were disappointed in the game for it having low visual quality in some areas, ie lesser NPCs and many textures. The game may lag hard if you have anti aliasing on highest, even on high end systems. The frame rate also caps at 30, and if you can't handle that.. well.. then this isn't for you I guess. I barely even notice the low frames, and the game is beautiful in many parts. I love how you can play as 12 different characters and can switch between them in combat, not to mention that every character is worth playing as and can be very fun. (Spare for Jack, I don't understand how to play him, he's slow) This is a good game, get it.

reviewText:
I have an extra 30 hours or so in this game from playing it before I bought it during the holliday sale on steam recently at 50% off. So far this is much better than Square's previous three FF games. FFXIII, XIII-2, and Lightning Returns. They all suffered from poor performance on pc from stutters and slowdown. Especially Lightning Returns which runs horribly. Performance aside, those three games just are not good examples of what Final Fantasy has been about over the years. Most true FF fans dislike them for good reason, although they are decent games in their own right. This game may be locked at 30fps but it still runs solid. Normally I am strongly against games that are fps locked at 30 on pc. In some cases it is downright god awful and near unplayable at 30fps (see: The Evil Within), but there are a few exceptions. With this type of game it doesn't matter because it isn't a action game where fluidity matters. This game has action combat but it is controlled through a lock-on system. It was ported from PSP so the 30 fps lock was unavoidable anyway.

I can say that I enjoy the gameplay in this much more than 13, 13-2, and Lightning returns all combined. I really dont like the combat or the move switching system very much in Lightning Returns. This game has that all beat by a mile. You can control 3 different characters at any time by switching with d-pad left or right (I use a xbox 360 controller which works great). Each character has four moves they can use during battle with X(attack), Y(special), A(defense/cure), and B(dodge), and you can customize their action loadout with different skills and spells. RB locks on and you can switch targets with RS left/right. It all works pretty easily and combat has a good flow to it. It is not confusing at all like Lightning Returns was, and you don't encounter unbeatable/nearly unbeatable enemies in the first area like in that game either. Most importantly though, you never feel rushed with a 13 day time limit like you were in Lightning Returns. I know I keep comparing it to that game when they are completely different feeling games but I can't help it because I really dislike the way they went with that game. Basically this game is just much better overall in terms of both gameplay and design and is much more true to the Final Fantasy name than 13, 13-2, and LR are.

The mission structure, rpg upgrade system, story advancement, character customization, music, sound, and overall game design meet the standard that was set by the last great FF game, FF12, one of the best ever. We probably will never see FF12 ported to pc, but this game is a decent example of what real FF tradition is.

7.5/10

reviewText:
If you are a fan of the series and enjoy the new mechanics that Square uses for each new Final Fantasy, than you will like this game.  I played all the other Final Fantasy's and love them.  I even played 13, which I enjoyed for the cinamatics and story mostly, the gameplay I thought was lackluster.  Final Fantasy Type-0 takes what 13 tried to do and it does a splendid job of delivering that.  I am only about 10 hours into the game right now, but the combat is very rewarding but takes awhile to get used to.  Oddly this game reminds me of a cross between Final Fantasy 8  (story wise) and Final Fantast 13 (gameplay, just drastically improved upon)

Pros:
-Fun
-New mechanic - action based gameplay (you control 1 hero while 2 others do battle alongside you)
-Engaging story - Feel like you are part of the world and guiding these poor souls through their own story
-Fast paced combat (compared to other FF games, you can end battles almost as soon as you start them)
-Over world map

Cons:
-controls get a bit wonky when you lock onto an enemy and they die.
-Sometimes felt like I missed something cause a character will mention somehting that I have no idea what or where it is.
-HD upgrade is a joke, the character rendering is laughable at times.
-Save often unlike other FF games where you can save almost anywhere, here you can only save at set areas.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The action packed gameplay in FF Type - 0 is definitely addicting and enjoyable. Each of the students seem to have a distinct fighting style with their own unique weapons. However, casting magic spells is generally the same for each student. On that note, they 'do' have character unique spell-like abilities which give the game added flavor.

The HD graphics are definitely noticable in the student's character models, but otherwise the graphics look rather mundane. Not terrible though. Keep in mind that you will spend most of your time interacting and controlling these main characters so most of what you see is very crisp and detailed character models.

The artwork in general fits the story setting very well and I find that the game itself most closely resembles FFVIII when compared to other FF games (ie: highschool age students thrust into a war due to their unique abilities).

I haven't beaten the game yet so I might write another review upon completion.
Cheers!
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I'm not entirely sure what all these negative reviews are for. I've experienced very few issues with the game. Despite the -ugh- 30fps lock, the game actually runs surprisingly smoothly. The camera is a bit janky, but the fast and fluid combat system is fun and engaging, to where it overshadows many issues. I run a mid range computer on Windows 10, that I built myself from the ground up 3 years ago. No stutter, and no fps drops. Your experience may be different from mine, but as long as you have a gamepad and a decent computer that matches the system requirements, you should be fine.\nA few complaints:\nThe story starts out extremely slow and makes little sense. The narrative jumps all over the place and it's very confusing. There is very little character development. All your characters are largely uninteresting and don't really offer anything special in the battlefield, so you'll be hard pressed to pick a few that you like the most and stick with them throughout the game, even though the game tells you to do otherwise. The graphics are reaaaaally dated, even though you're playing in 1080p. Textures and models are all blocky and very underdetailed. Although, I'm willing to excuse that because this WAS a PSP game. I'm happy I get to play this game at all, considering it was originally supposed to be a Japan-only game. But it was definitely worth it for me. Very fun.

reviewText: Ignore the mixed reviews. This game is very fun, and I can recommend it to anyone who loves real time combat action that is fluid with the gameplay, and to anyone who loves a good story. This game is darker than the other FF titles, so be ready for that. I believe people were disappointed in the game for it having low visual quality in some areas, ie lesser NPCs and many textures. The game may lag hard if you have anti aliasing on highest, even on high end systems. The frame rate also caps at 30, and if you can't handle that.. well.. then this isn't for you I guess. I barely even notice the low frames, and the game is beautiful in many parts. I love how you can play as 12 different characters and can switch between them in combat, not to mention that every character is worth playing as and can be very fun. (Spare for Jack, I don't understand how to play him, he's slow) This is a good game, get it.

reviewText: Another great Final Fantasy Spin-off, that feels meant for fans of the spin-offs. The fact this is an updated port of a PSP game means the graphics are uneven and the environments are very small. However, this keeps the game tight and fast-paced. reviewText:
Actually one of the better new FF games alongside Lightning Returns. I really dig them going back to more open worlds like before FFX. The combat is also really fun since you actually controll the characters and when the swing. I really don't think we will get the full turn based combat back but at least I feel like I am playing the game unlike FF13-2.
Most textures aren't the best here but it is a PSP port so that is to be expected.
Like with all the FF games with voice acting, turn the voices to japanese and put on english subtitles.

While this is certainly no comparison to FF6-10 it is much better than many of them in between X and Lightning Returns. Even then this game won't be for every fan of the series. My only real gripe with type-0 is the camera in combat can flip out on occaision and they dump a metric ton of lore on you right from the start. Which actually isn't bad but can be a bit overwhelming at first.

reviewText:
Want to read about the game itself? I'll save the technical details for the end. I have already played through Type-0 entirely on the PS4, and I'm currently playing this version. It's not a normal Final Fantasy game. It's darker and more mature (hence the 'M' rating), but at the core there is still plenty of Final Fantasy to be had here.

It's action-oriented, but I find the combat to be very satisfying. The story, although a bit hard to follow at times, ends up being quite memorable & touching, especially if you play it through twice to unlock the full ending. The music is great, which is to be expected from a Final Fantasy game.

Swapping between characters on the fly, each with a very different playstyle, makes for some engaging and varied combat. You've got to learn the strengths and weaknesses of your team to fully utilize them. It takes getting used to, but by the end of your first playthrough you'll have the hang of it, and you'll likely want to go through the New Game + mode with your new skills. As such, it's highly replayable.

Play it with a controller. Let me just get that out of the way. The keyboard and mouse controls are quite difficult. You may also want to turn off the motion blur and set the camera speed to slow, especially if motion sickness is an issue for you.  Also, if you have a g-sync monitor, you need to disable g-sync for this game. It will make the cutscenes choppy.

Other than that, it runs as expected at a very smooth frame rate. It is a better port than XIII or XIII-2. Unfortunately, the highest resolution is currently 1080p. I fully expect a patch to be released to allow for higher resolutions, but just be aware that currently this is as high as you can go.

I know a lot of people will have gripes about the 30 FPS lock. Those people would do well to remember that this is a PSP port, and it's not a matter of simply clicking a button and allowing 60 FPS. The game's underlying systems and animations were designed for a mobile device. Yes, all new games ought to have 60+ FPS, but it's unrealistic to expect them to entirely remake this game to allow for that.

Bottom line: If you can't play a 30 FPS game in 1080p or lower and enjoy it, skip this game. If you are a fan of the Final Fantasy series, check this one out and support Square Enix so they continue to give us more games on PC. It's unique and refreshing; yet it still has chocobos, moogles, flyable air ships, and a world map like the Final Fantasy games you love. New to the Final Fantasy series? If you like combining action with strategy, check it out!

reviewText:
Okay, so I played the game for a few minutes now and noticed that the game is capped at a low framerate. Possibly around 30 fps. Because I've been playing 60 fps games for a while, this change is so noticeable and somehow different on my eyes, somehow strains my eyes on extended gameplay hours/minutes. Anyway, this doesn't stop me from playing this wonderful game! Really dark setting, nice gameplay and story, somehow nice graphics. I was expecting this to be a complete remake on HD but I guess that would be too much for a game that's already been released on the PSP around 4 years ago. Anyway, the improvement from the PSP version isn't that much since the PSP game already offers what Type-0 could offer on any systems it will be released on. Except the updated graphics and added features in this HD release. Well, that's for me at least. Anyway, I'm still thankful for Square Enix for releasing this for western audience as well as being a PC port, They really did well this time! Cheers to SE!

Pros:
Updated HD Graphics for Main Characters and Some Environment
Nice Story, Dark theme
Somehow tricky gameplay when played first on the PSP version, but is customizable and is nice.
Nice voice acting, specially if you like Japanese voice <3

Cons:
Low framerate, seems to be capped at 30 fps. Hope some fix for this in future updates...
Motion blur doesn't look to good to me... Made me dizzy on my first 10 minutes of gameplay...
No Vibration on Controller
The pre-rendered cutscenes look like the PSP version that has been upscaled a bit...
Some characters textures not looking HD enough. Specially those dress that look muddy or pixelated. Some environment textures also look pixelated, such as floor textures, some low polygons on environment edges, noticeeable on field area between land and water.

Gonna update this review sometime soon, Currently playiing on these PC specs with no graphical or technical problems so far, except for that 30 fps cap....

Microsoft Windows 10 Pro
Intel Core i5-4690k @ 3.5GHz
XFX Radeon R9 290X Double Dissipation 4GB GDDR5
4GB+4GB Dual Channel 1600MHz RAM
2+4TB Seagate HDD
DualShock 4 with DS4Windows for Gamepad

1080p Fullscreen
High Spec Graphic Settings
Motion Blur turned off (Since I get dizzy most of the time with that even on Weak)

Overall, Like this game so much~ Thank you Square Enix~

reviewText:
Let's ditch all complaints about the port and the fact that this is psp game. After all, there are plenty really good psp games on steam (legend of heroes/ys for example) and talk abou t the game itself.
You know, despite what everyone is saying I really liked the gameplay. Yeah, world map pretty empty and ai could be better, but overall it quite fun. SE just took crisis core combat and upgraded it, and they have also added some missions and a lot of pleasant features and secrets. There are a lot of hidden stuff, bosses, mini games and stuff, also, missions there self are pretty challenging. Gameplay wise this game fantastic! The problem is in the stuff that happening BETWEEN missions.

Right after the moment a started playing there is one annoying questing start to bother me: Is this a Final Fantasy or Call of Duty??? I mean really, ff was always about guys, who fight there personal demons and save the world along the way. As naive as that sounds, it always was an emotional and compelling experience. I always liked Sakaguchi's naive simpleness, and the way he handles eternal questions. In this game, however, main characters are just puppets of some kind of overly complex experiment. And so they are fighting in the war because their government told them to do so! Compelling? As hell.
The next thing that putted me off is the way the story is served to you. Millions of overly lengthy cutscenes! Tons of stupid and badly voiced dialogs! In the end I just skipped all cutscenes with crying stop babbling and let me just get to the action!" And that isn't the reason because you should play jrpg! Hack and slash games
recommended: but not RPGs!\nAnd finally what kills me about this game it is the fact that it want you to experience emotional feelings that it didn't deserve! Who is this guy in the early beginning? Why we should care about him? Why we shall care about any of characters in this game since almost nobody of them has a personality? That's quite a riddle to me.\nSo
voteText: keep that in mind if you will want play this game."

reviewText:
I won't even comment on how bad the port is, since i could live with it's flaws.

What really makes me not recommend this game is the game itself. This is the worst FF i've played. Don't get me wrong, the game has some good points, like the fact that you have 14 characters with different styles, and music and voice acting (japanese dub) are really good, but those are really the only good points.

The story is boring and fails to make me really want to know what will happen next. The characters are all 1 dimension (an optimistic one, an intelectual one, a clumsy one, etc...) with almost 0 development, which doesn't help with creating a bound between the player and the characters. The ending is nice but looses much impact due to the fact that there's a lack of bounding with the characters.

The grinding is just a pain. I usually don't find grind all that bad, hell one of my favourite game is Monster Hunter which is a grind fest, but here is just a pain to kill the same enemy hundreds of times to level up 14 characters. They should made the game so that all characters get exp when you kill a monster.

Still if you are a big fan of FF like me, buy it, but if you don't really care about playing all FF and can live with only playing the main series ones, just skip this one.

reviewText:
Warning: This review is bound to be subjective.

Look past the mixed reviews it has gotten - this is a PC port of a PSP game and it shows in the graphics and probably the optimization. Sure it was kind of rushed out, but keep reading.

The Pros:  Runs stable
Action packed combat system
An entire cast of 14 characters to play
Every character feels very unique, they all have their very own style of play
Great story
An overworld similiar to those of older Final Fantasy titles
Different types of missions that spice the gameplay up a bit
Lots of unlockable lore tidbits in the Crystarium
A pretty fair ranking system for missions
Any Mission can be replayed from the main menu to get a better rank if you wish
Good challenge later into the game
The Cons: Bad controls for keyboard and mouse, i would even say unplayable. You NEED a gamepad, and a XBOX 360 one at that, since it doesn't support others. However you can use JoyToKey with other gamepads, ands it works fine, but remember to turn on the NumLock so your camera works with the stick you bind it to. Also turn on all axis in JoyToKey.
Extremely muddy and low-res textures on most characters that aren't your protagonists or someone important to the story
Not too many graphics options
Optimization isn't perfect
The camera can be a little bit obnoxious at times
There are battles that you have to lose, at least in your first playthrough. (But said boss battles have a much higher lvl boss than your level is, so you will most likely notice which ones you are allowed to lose)
I want to note that i am playing this game on a PC with a normal GTX750 (not the titan version) with 6 x 3.5GHz and 8 GB RAM. The game runs smooth and stable without any FPS drops for me - that is if i have anti-aliasing set to [Off]. With AA, my framerate drops down to about 15. I guess this is a issue on my end though, since my specs aren't exactly high-end. You can definately play this game without problems if you can live without AA.

That said, this game is one of my favorite games ever, although it's not a perfect game, and much less a perfect port. For a HD" re-release

reviewText:
I understand people are experiencing legitimite issues. That will hopefully be remedied with either an official or unofficial (fan-made) patch.

Say what you want about the textures, the 30 fps lock. I get it.

But this was a PSP game. If you expected stunning textures, the devs would have had to rebuild the entire game from the ground up. It is what it is. Personally, the 30 fps lock actually bothers me much less than I originally thought it would.

The camera is clunky in battle just as it was in the PSP version. I was hoping this would be improved upon, but it hasn't. It will take some getting used to and camera manipulation actually becomes - unintentionally - a skill based mechanic in itself.

My only complaint is that for some reason the steam overlay does not work while in game, which means I can't take Steam screenshots and I also get no notifications when I earn an achievement. This erks me, and hopefully a solution is found soon.

^ This can be worked around by closing any GPU monitoring/tweaking software such as MSI Afterburner, EVGA Precision and RivaTuner Statistics Server. Not really a fix, but a workaround.
One more minor thing that detracts from the visuals is that there is a strange blur over character's faces. Not motion blur - something different all together, and I havent figured out a way to get rid of it.

^ This can be vastly improved upon by disabling Antialiasing in the game Launcher and forcing it to what you want in your GPU control panel. It seems that Type-0's AA is rather lackluster.
If you can accept the fact there is a 30 fps lock, and that it isn't graphically groundbreaking even as a remaster (cough..PSP game.. cough) and you like fast paced JRPG's with a lots (I mean come on... there's 14 characters in your group, not including Summons) of customization and an immersive story, you can't go wrong here - even with the apparent issues.

Also, I should mention that there is a grindy aspect to the game at points. Sometimes you are forced to grind to a certain level in order to meet mission requirements, or else be under-leveled and risk getting your *ace* handed to you. The good news is - in my opinion - that the combat never becomes dull and there is always new tactics you can experiment with to find what works best and to discover your personal play style.

reviewText:
Before I bought the game, I'd already expect it to be a horrible port. It's no surprise there since its a port from the one and only SquareEnix (in case you don't already know, infamous for their HORRIBLE PC port). Fortunately, there's the option to use the controller so I'd definitely recommend using a controller to play the game. If you're looking for a game with a good story regarding wars with a gameplay similar to Final Fantasy VII: Crisis Core, you'll definitely enjoy this game. I've already put in more than 5 hours of game time and even though its a sh*tty port, I still enjoyed it. The game is meant to be a grindy, long game and it has tons and tons of content with bunch of insights on the history of the world of FF13.

Gameplay is unique and its a very fresh concept for a Final Fantasy game. Like I had said, the combat is sorta like a mix FF7: Crisis Core except it's more fast paced and rewards finesse gameplay. There's definitely a lot of room for character skills customization till the point where its almost overwheming (Because of the insane numbers of playable characters).
One of my favourite part of the game was being able to play as Eidolons, like ODIN. (OPOPOP)

Of course, regardless of the PC port, the voice acting is.... not good, gave me goosebumps alldayevrrydey. I haven't tried this yet but I think it'll be a better experience to just turn on the subtitles and switch the voice audio from English to Japanese. Also you'll need to take the initiative to read up on the in-game codex regarding the war and world and stuff or you probably won't be able to understand what is going on.

Oh yea, there's also a problem with my audio where there's weird popping sound during the first few scenes. Other than that it sounds normal (maybe it's just my headphones idk). And the music is AMAZING as always, exactly what I'd expect from a final fantasy game.

Welp, if you still can't decide where or not to get the game, just try it for an hour and if you don't like it, just get a refund. I think the game is worth getting it (not to mention free doto items) even though sometimes it could feel like a very lazy port from the awesome PSP version of the game.

reviewText:
This is a decent game, but don't expect it to come near any of the main series.

The focus here is mainly on the gameplay and it is the strongest point of the whole package, alongside the soundtrack. There are 14 different characters that you can play as right from the start, allowing you to experiment and find the right combination that will compliment your playing style. The combat is solid for the most part, though towards the end it becomes more of a who can one-shot the other faster" game.

reviewText:
Note: I waited until well after it had been thoroughly patched and encountered no graphical or performance issues.

Unfortunately FF Type-O is an incredibly clunky game despite the combat aping the mainline Kingdom Hearts games, every controllable character feels awkward and the camera often jerks about, ramming into walls or staying locked on to dead targets. Admittedly that last feature is because once an enemy is downed you can harvest phantoma from them, but it's still garbage.

The story is boring, and the cast and setting are just a gussied up FFVIII but without the hilariously bad dialogue and fun to be had from breaking the game over your knee.

A very unimpressive game.

reviewText:
I'm gonna start by saying the gameplay is fun, but...
This game is so complex, you have 12 characters to assign skills and equipment and unlike the main games in the Final Fantasy series you have to use all these characters, or at least more than 3 depending on your skill and difficulty. Oh and you have 2 slots for skills and magic together on each character, and you learn so many skills so early and the magic is so good 2 slots are not enough, at least give 2 slots for each.
And all this is just the complex parts in characters part, then there is gameplay and how the game works.
All that being said the game is good for people who have a lot of time and patience.
P.S. As a HUGE fan of the Final Fantasy series (i own like 90% of all releases including spinoffs and ♥♥♥♥) i will say that unfortuantely it is not a very good Final Fantasy game, but a decent one as just a game"

reviewText:
The game caught a lot of negative attention with its port to steam. 30 fps?! Texture resolutions?! And just like that, negative/mixed reviews. Now, don't get me wrong. I'm a 60 fps ♥♥♥♥♥, myself, but I'm not naive enough to expect a PSP to PC port to blow me away with its performance and graphics.

Before I dive too far into the game review, I will say that the game's story is incomplete on its own. Squeenix saw it fit to make the complete story spread across two games and a novel. That being said, there are plot holes and it will require some external research to get the whole story. This in itself is aggrivating, and I wish I knew this before jumping in.

That being said, Final Fantasy Type-0 is an enjoyable experience that doesn't overstay its welcome. Character progression isn't complex. You level up, pick a few skills to build on, and go on your way. You can alter your magic spells by spending the souls that you harvest from your fallen enemies, changing cast time, mp cost, power, etc. The new game plus system is a nice touch, especially since it ties in with the story... sort of. The varied gameplay for the characters is a nice touch, since everyone has their own fighting style and feel. Unfortunately there is a massive void of characterization and development in the game. Is it due to the PSP nature of the game forcing them to hold out on cutscenes? I don't know. All that I know is that outside of Rem and Machina, there isn't much development, and even theirs is minimal. All of the characters feel like cardboard cut-outs that are based on the typical Japanese stereotypes, and while this is usually a serious negative...

This is a Final Fantasy game. Anyone experienced with the Final Fantasy series knows to not expect amazing character or story development. We've been fed silent characters that look for the crystals because plot stuff
date:
and we enjoyed it. Final Fantasy has never been about the incredible writing or amazing character dialogue. It's been about the grind, the summons/magic, the flashyness of the designs, and the girly-man villians. The story and characters are just a bonus.

The grind is there if you want it. It's not necessary, thanks to the difficulty system and the new game + system, but it's there if you want to over level. Leveling doesn't increase your stats by a whole lot, but damage/defense is highly based on level and equipment. There are stat boosting items that are farmable if you are looking to max your stats.

Magic is ridiculous in this game. Not only is it the hardest hitting form of damage that you can do, but you can make it aoe or have homing. From 5 seconds into the game all the way until you finish it, magic is useful (unless the enemies are immune, which is rare). And Ultima... dear god Ultima is great in this game. It breaks the damage cap if 9999, its radius is huge, and it is visually satisfying.

Summons are quite strong as well. I didn't use them much, since I didn't prep a reraise to rez my summoner, and I really didn't want yet another character to level. Storywise, Summoning is pretty incredible, and gives it a reason to be feared by both the summoning party and the recipients of the summon's aggression.

With all of that being said, I do need to address some of the negatives to this game. There are really only two that I will cover, but they need to be covered, none-the-less. The camera is awful. Locking on to a target moves the camera to be at ground level, making the game trigger claustrophobia even worse than it already did with its ridiculously narrow field of view (PSP constraint). Nothing could have been done with the port to PC with this, but it's still frustrating.

PC Port-wise, the keyboard and mouse controls. Jesus tap-dancing Christ. Whoever designed this part of the game needs to be fired. Twice. The absolute least that they could have done was add the keymapping to a .ini file, but no, that would be too hard, I suppose.

TLDR: If you're a Final Fantasy fan, get it and enjoy it. If you're an action RPG fan, buy it, but try to make up your mind within two hours of gameplay in case you want to cash in on that refund. Oh, and buy a controller, you'll need it.

reviewText:
So, what did I think of this game? Well, for the most part I quite enjoyed the gameplay and combat, although it did take a little while to get used to. I also really liked doing the strategy missions where you conquer certain regions. They were kind of an interesting addition to the game. But, my gripes with this game mostly rely on the story and characters.

There's a huge variety of characters in Class Zero; 14 perfect-looking teenagers who are mostly just walking stereotypes, and I found it difficult to be invested in any of them because I found them all to be so...bland. I did my best to go through all the dialogue and extra scenes in the game, hoping to feel SOMETHING for the characters, but I just couldn't, which is quite a disappointment.

If I had to choose between them, I'd end up choosing which ones I like PLAYING the most rather than ones who I like the personalities of, in which case that would be Sice and Seven. Seven I particularly like literally only because she bears SUCH a resemblance to Lightning.

I get it, though, there's 14 of them so I suppose it'd be difficult to give them all equal screentime and development, but still. They could've done more to flesh them out a little. I mean, in the beginning I couldn't even tell some of the guys apart cause they all had similar-colored blond hair.

And as for the story, as far as I'm concerned there really isn't one. It's mostly your typical we're-at-war" storyline with some cataclysmic event phoned-in at the end for the sake of having an epic and campy final boss. Granted
date: the stories in FF games have never been THAT groundbreakingly amazing
recommended: but that's what the characters are supposed to be there for
hoursPlayed: y'know? But even the characters weren't enough to make me care about the story in this one.\n\nSo yeah

reviewText:
I always wanted to play this game ever since it came out years ago on the psp. I heard lots of good reviews about it. I recommend this game IF you have a PC and a good graphic card to run it.

At first the game was unplayable and it took me lots of tries to figure out why it was lagging so bad. The reason was that my GPU card wasn't selected. So I had to lower the game specs and it looked horrid. I almost complained and wanted a refund. BUT I was able to fix it by using boosters and messing around with the GPU for high performance and it looks amazing!!!!! No lag and it's gorgeous in my opinion.

I'm happy I gave it another try before deciding to return it. I'm really enjoying it!

reviewText:
To start, I'd like to say that I acknowledge the fact that this is originally a PSP game. However, PSP games are not PC games, and therefore this game has to be judged on a PC scale. I'd also like to say that I'm a fan of the FF series and that bias may slip through somewhat.
The game starts in a way that I've not seen in the FF's that I've played; which is to say, brutal mass murder. A person that you think could be the hero dies slowly and painfully with his chocobo. This immediate dark take on the beginning of the game could be indicitave of how the rest of the plot is going to play out, but I've yet to complete it. However, the plot so far has intrigue, and is a pretty classic FF storyline.
How this plot is told, however, is a little weak in my opinion. Along with cutscenes, there will be an omniscient narrator feeding to you what is happening, and sometimes in place of what could have just been another cutscene. This, to me, is lazy writing. However, that alone isn't nearly reason enough to drop the game.
The characters, right now, aren't that fleshed out. This is probably because I'm at the start of the game and most characters in the Final Fantasy series usually don't have their personalities written out until a few hours into the game.
The voice acting in English is pretty good until you get to some of the more minor cutscenes. It sometimes feels like Glados is the one who told these people what syllables to stress, and while you can tell that it's trying to be an American accent, it gets a little inconsistent for no apparent reason. Again, I'd like to say the voice acting in general is good and there's no instances of Engrish" so far.
One thing that's worth noting is that the English voice sync with the mouth movements are a bit... Off... to say the least. I haven't played it in Japanese yet
date: so I've yet to see whether this is because of poor syncing just to English or both versions.\nTo call this an "HD" game is somewhat of a stretch. Your graphics options are limited by the engine and the character models outside of major cutscenes are a bit lacking. You're also locked at a 30 fps maximum. While I understand that's because this is a PSP game
recommended: it still can't be judged as such because it's on a different platform.\nControls are fairly easy to get used to

Character and story are mediocre at best. I've got many more cons but don't feel like giving a full review. All in all, game is kind of good but not good enough to recommend to other final fantasy fans.

reviewText:
Best Final Fantasy Port On PC

Total = 7/10


It runs consistently. Lets you turn off blur and annoying effects. You can mod in resolution options.
The english voice acting while not great, is not as horrible as it was made out to be. (IE it's not worse than FFX or lightning returns imo).


Pro's
-The story and setting is wholly unique for final fantasy. It has the politics of FFXII, however, the banter between characters is there. The dialogue is also much better than the FFXIII series.
-The combat system is great, however the camera is always marring the combat system.
-Overall it is a great HD port. The main issue is that the source material is from the PSP.

Negatives
-30 FPS
-You have to mod to get resolutions other than 1080p or 720p.
-It was obviously designed for PSP. The level areas are small and some textures are horrible.
-The camera.

Mainly I think it could be a 8/10 game. I take 0.5 points off for the camera, and 0.5 points off for the small areas. The skeleton of the game is ambitious and a ton of fun.

reviewText:
Specs of my laptop:
Intel® Core™ i7-3630QM 2.4GHz
NVIDIA GeForce GT730M with 4GB dedicated VRAM
8GB RAM
Widows 8 Pro 64-bit

UPDATE(23/09/2015): Now the game has more resolutions when in fullscreen mode and the most important thing is, MOUSE SUPPORT! You can finally move the camera with your mouse. Sadly, there isn't a mouse sensitivity settings in the game so I suppose the camera moves depending on your mouse DPI, so if you find the camera to be really slow, increase the DPI of your mouse.

Now lets start with a few simple things.
GRAPHICS
Since everyone is SO concerned about the graphics, I decide to talk about this first. The game is locked at 30FPS because it is a PSP PORT. People just tends to forget that part and starts complaining. If you are facing problems such as low FPS when playing, Lower your anti-aliasing settings. I had my AA on normal and the the rest on (except for motion blur, I turned that off) and the game runs smoothly. Cutscenes do seem a bit of a lower res than the rest of the game, so don't jusdge the game just from the cutscenes. Hop in game and start moving around to get the actual picture.

CONTROLS (OUTDATED)
I will have to say I am disappointed in the controls of this game. The keyboard controls are unplayable, that is for sure. You can't change the keyboard settings to whatever you want as well. I would advise people to play this game with a controller. If you don't have a controller (like me), you can try something else. I have a Steelseries Rival, I made a profile just for this game, changing my Mouse 1 button to F and Mouse 2 to backspace so that I can use my mouse to attack in game while I move using the keyboard. I have the camera fixed so I don't really have to worry much. In the end, it is down to personal preference.

GAMEPLAY
I only played the game for 45minutes (according to my save file). Overall, combat is fun, story seems decent. I haven't met any game breaking bugs or crashes so far.

TLDR (UPDATED ON 23/09/2015)
It is a great game, just not a really good port. The controls are better now thanks to the mouse support. But it can be rather slow if your DPI is low, and there isn't a mouse sensitivity settings. So for now, you will just have to increase the DPI of your mouse if you want to increase the camera speed. But hey, at least the game is getting better~

reviewText:
I've not played the PSP version of this for reference but the HDness appears to be limited to the main character models and textures, perhaps some visual effects as well. The rest of the world looks pretty low res, but pretty characters and DOF make it HD enough for me :P

I grew tired of the battle system(ended up cheating), reason I kept playing was because I found the story compelling and I wanted to see what would happen dispite it having extremely annoying parts. The game starts with an invasion and all of the main characters are introduced very quickly, this annoyed me as there wasn't much character development appart from knowing that they were named after playing cards and there personalities fall into typical japanese archetypes. There's the dumb blond, the delinquent, the tough guy, the philosophical guy, happy go lucky, the class rep etc etc.  Lots of elements to the lore are mentioned without much explanation which left me quite confused for alot of the game.  The plot also uses deus ex machina ALOT which is a kind of cop out in my opinion....'ah ♥♥♥♥ game over....oh wait..I'm still alive eh?!'  but in the end I really rather enjoyed watching the plot unfold.

In summary you need to remember this is a PSP port and it still plays as such, the story is dark and shocking in places. if you can overcome its short comings it is an enjoyable game.

reviewText:
As a FF title, you get what you pay for. It feels like it could be a handheld game -- which makes sense, it's ported from the PSP (afaik). But, it's a good title. The game could be thought of as broken into two or three categories: missions, and their derivatives, and the time you spend on campus at Akademia. How you choose to spend your time on campus is pretty much up to you. Spent carefully, you will gain insight and learn interesting information about Class Zero and individuals that come to Akademia.
Missions are exactly what this game was sold on. FFT0 probably comes off as an action game, and that's because it is. Combat is hectic, chaotic even. If you have played kingdom hearts, the combat is a bit like that, but even more fast paced and much elss forgiving. You'll be scratching your head wondering why you're dead at times. Take it with stride, and learn from your mistakes. The game rewards you for doing that. If you time your attacks right, you could do massive damage or even kill an opponent outright.
Overall, the gameplay can feel a bit repetitive. It's not a game I can pick up and -not- put down. It's something that I like playing for a while, then taking a break from. The mixture of character development and satisfying, fast paced combat will keep you coming back.

reviewText:
Do not buy this game if you are using PC controls! They are super buggy and some of the worst pc controls I have ever used on any pc port ever. The game itself is great but seriously, you are going to be disappointed if you dont have a controller.

Let me explain the controls for the mouse users.

Put your cursor in the middle of your screen and hold down left click and move towards the top of your screen to move forward. Then move it back to the middle to stop moving. Then release left click and hold down right click. And then move your cursor left to look left. Then move it back to the center to stop rotating view.

Now for straight keyboard users..... Poor keyboard users.
Use the arrow keys to move your character (not your point of view) and then hit tab to re center your point of view in the direction your character is facing. Oh and you are going to want to remap like all of the default controls. To dodge (while moving) press backspace. Lol.... Its bad.

reviewText:
Here are some take-aways if you're thinking about getting this game.

- This game is a port of a PSP game from 2011. It got a slight graphical upgrade but don't expect it to be Witcher quality. Some of the textures will still be quite ugly.
- 30 FPS locked, but the game plays smoothly.
- Do not buy this game if you don't have a controller.
- The camera is really fast and jets all over the place. This futher emphasizes the need for a controller. You need to move/dodge the moment the camera jerks around, a keyboard/mouse combo makes this more complicated than necessary.

The game itself is fun. Kind of a Dark Souls lite with jrpg elements. There's 14 characters with all unique weapons and customization. I got the game on sale and think it's an amazing purchase for 20$.

reviewText:
The GAME IS TOTALLY Ok and working charm. At 720p it works without drops on a old Athlon II X3 @ OC'd 3'2 GHz with a NVIDIA 640 GT. No tearing, the only problem is the audio sync is bit off.

Want 1440p/2160p? You have G-Sync? You have FreeSync? So don't buy this game, be for real SquareENIX does NOT care you, you're only the 1,26% of Steam.

The high end computers users all need to know AA HIGH and VERY HIGH gives you an 1080p downscale from x1.5 and x2.25 to native game resolution.

The game is weird? Some textures looks like the size of my fist? YES, but this is the game (I don't know how it is on other plataforms). I like it. Hope you buy this and enjoy it.

reviewText:
Let it be known that even though the port might be pretty bad, the game in itself is great. This WAS a PSP game after all and I'm pretty happy to have gotten the opportunity to play the game on PC than not at all since I don't own a PS4 or a PSP/Vita. The game works perfectly fine for me a runs on a consistant 30fps where some of my friends have told me that they experienced some fps drops on PS4.

Although if you don't have monitors that support a 16:9 ratio I'd wait until they patch in all the other resolutions like they did for the 13 series. And to address the framerate issue - just like 13 and 13-2 anti-aliasing is another fancy term for downsampling and setting it on Highest" would make your internal resolution render at 4k. So unless you're running on a crazy setup I'd turn that option down to "Normal" or turn it off completely to have an enjoyable experience.

Also

reviewText:
Graphics: 8.5/10 up to par in some areas but some things still have psp textures, not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you. It's pretty weird some people look CG the npcs look psp-ish, the game looks odd.

Gameplay: Took a while to get used to but pretty well thought out, not fond of having to have more than one soldier in that field area that gets on my nerves but thankfully it can be just one soldier at a time on missions.
There's a lot of them to choose from and all of them have completely different attacks and weapons except for some baselines abilities. There's even a really basic rts mode on some of the missions too. 9/10 Remove mandatory reserves and it's golden.

Story:Paid alittle more attention to it, eh it's alright but meh. Similar to ff12 where you fight oppression or something, with magister-like whatever with them bigass helmets you know em when you see em.

Level design: Large scale, interesting to say the least. They took the wild arms 3 approach with this.
Combat:Dark souls and crisis core all the way. Really feels like that ingame. Right down to the boss fights it really feels like a hybrid souls game with a lighter tone.

Recommended only to those who like games like this. Highly doubt it'll please everybody but it does what it does very well, for an rpg.

One thing I wish every rpg had is that it lets you train the character without even playing the game, could be doin somethin else and the character chosen levels up alittle, that needs to be in more rpgs cuz it's done very well.

reviewText:
Update:

August 23, 2015

Updated to recommended. Really enjoyed the game, I guess the pros outweigh the cons. I was also able to fix the resolution issue using 'Borderless Gaming'. P.S. F11 (snapshot mode) = profit.

- -

August 21, 2015

I like the gameplay, pretty fun so far despite the horrendous PC port. There's inconsistent texture quality throughout the game, I was expecting better from the screenshots. I also had to fix my graphics driver because the game uses my integrated graphics card by default.

More details:

1. The game is 30 fps locked, not a big issue for me. But I experienced frames at 10~20 fps and had to go to my graphics settings to make sure the game uses my NVIDIA card instead of Intel's integrated graphics.

2. Inconsistent quality of graphics/textures. Some parts of the game looks nice, while others still look like you're playing from the PSP. I was expecting more from an HD remaster on PC.

3. This port has only either 720p or 1080p resolution. My laptop has a 900p resolution so it doesn't look too appealing on full screen. I had to keep it on a window that occupies only 65% of my screen.

4. People seem to be having trouble playing it on a keyboard and mouse. Highly recommended to use a controller, preferably Xbox controller for Windows.

Unless you're playing on a 1080p screen and have a good controller, I don't fully recommend purchasing this game as it is right now. Maybe after they fix the resolution and textures or after I fully enjoy the game.

Although if you don't have monitors that support a 16:9 ratio I'd wait until they patch in all the other resolutions like they did for the 13 series. And to address the framerate issue - just like 13 and 13-2 anti-aliasing is another fancy term for downsampling and setting it on Highest" would make your internal resolution render at 4k. So unless you're running on a crazy setup I'd turn that option down to "Normal" or turn it off completely to have an enjoyable experience.

reviewText:
I'm going to open up this review saying that it's honestly a shame that this game is getting such mixed reviews. To first put it all into perspective this was a port from a PSP game so I was going in not expecting everything to come out perfectly as it would have if it was a port from something like the PS3. I also want to point out that almost 80% of the negative reviews are from players who have played an hour or less of the game and should be taken with a grain of salt. But I will have to say learning from some of their frustrations this game is very difficult to play with a keyboard and a game pad is almost required, and the settings of the game should be played around with most notably the camera speed.

First thing that I would like to comment on is the battle system. It is actually quite fun and intense at times which brings much contrast to the other games from Final Fantasy as it is more of a Hack and Slash to a lesser extent. I would liken it to the battle system of Kingdom Hearts with a couple key differences. Overall though I did enjoy the battle system, however i did find most of the boss fights to leave something to be desired as most of them were just straightforward and not as satisfying as boss fights normally are in Final Fantasy games. i feel that the game only becomes actually challenging once the player finishes the game once and enters NG+ (Agito Mode). That being said I did find the battle system quite refreshing and did enjoy it quite a lot.

Second is the story. The story follows Fabula Nova Crystallis series which is that of Final Fantasy 13  and a couple others, which is honestly a bit confusing to start but once you start to get further into the game it makes a bit more sense. I thought the story was very entertaining with a lot of twists to it which kept the game very interesting all throughtout. The only thing that frustrated me to no end when I was only a few hours into the game is how confusing the naming of the countries were. They follow the 4 Beasts of Asian mythology which is Suzaku, Genbu, Byakko, and Seiryu which are all tied to a country Rubrum, Lorica, Militesi, and Concordia respectively. The problem is that they use words like the Dominion, Suzaku, Vermillion Bird, and Rubrum interchangably which is really confusing until you actually associate what goes with what. But overall that is just a minor thing that annoyed me.

Overall, I did think the game is quite good and the graphics are not as bad as people put them out to be in the negative reviews. The game does come with a fair bit of confusing points and takes a bit to get used to but I assure you that after playing it for a bit it is actually a very enjoyable game.

reviewText:
Graphics: 8.5/10 up to par in some areas but some things still have psp textures, not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you. It's pretty weird some people look CG the npcs look psp-ish, the game looks odd.

Gameplay: Took a while to get used to but pretty well thought out, not fond of having to have more than one soldier in that field area that gets on my nerves but thankfully it can be just one soldier at a time on missions.
There's a lot of them to choose from and all of them have completely different attacks and weapons except for some baselines abilities. There's even a really basic rts mode on some of the missions too. 9/10 Remove mandatory reserves and it's golden.

Story:Paid alittle more attention to it, eh it's alright but meh. Similar to ff12 where you fight oppression or something, with magister-like whatever with them bigass helmets you know em when you see em.

Level design: Large scale, interesting to say the least. They took the wild arms 3 approach with this.
Combat:Dark souls and crisis core all the way. Really feels like that ingame. Right down to the boss fights it really feels like a hybrid souls game with a lighter tone.

Recommended only to those who like games like this. Highly doubt it'll please everybody but it does what it does very well, for an rpg.

One thing I wish every rpg had is that it lets you train the character without even playing the game, could be doin somethin else and the character chosen levels up alittle, that needs to be in more rpgs cuz it's done very well.

reviewText:
Update:

August 23, 2015

Updated to recommended. Really enjoyed the game, I guess the pros outweigh the cons. I was also able to fix the resolution issue using 'Borderless Gaming'. P.S. F11 (snapshot mode) = profit.

- -

August 21, 2015

I like the gameplay, pretty fun so far despite the horrendous PC port. There's inconsistent texture quality throughout the game, I was expecting better from the screenshots. I also had to fix my graphics driver because the game uses my integrated graphics card by default.

More details:

1. The game is 30 fps locked, not a big issue for me. But I experienced frames at 10~20 fps and had to go to my graphics settings to make sure the game uses my NVIDIA card instead of Intel's integrated graphics.

2. Inconsistent quality of graphics/textures. Some parts of the game looks nice, while others still look like you're playing from the PSP. I was expecting more from an HD remaster on PC.

3. This port has only either 720p or 1080p resolution. My laptop has a 900p resolution so it doesn't look too appealing on full screen. I had to keep it on a window that occupies only 65% of my screen.

4. People seem to be having trouble playing it on a keyboard and mouse. Highly recommended to use a controller, preferably Xbox controller for Windows.

Unless you're playing on a 1080p screen and have a good controller, I don't fully recommend purchasing this game as it is right now. Maybe after they fix the resolution and textures or after I fully enjoy the game.

reviewText:
Previously i placed a bad rating but now i changed it to a recommendation since i found out some issues could be fixed on my own, i am still waiting for the FF XIII fix.

I have just played about 2 hours of the game, the graphics are good (but not quite on par with most current pc games), the story is great! and the controls are well done, i use a DS3 gamepad with SCP drivers, i haven't used the keyboard/mouse so i can't comment on that.

In the beginning i had issues running the game in proper full screen with my 1366 x 768 monitor but by forcing the aspect ratio on my NVIDIA Control Panel it got fixed.

The graphics look well for a PSP game but the textures are all blurry and low/medium resolution (see my screenshots) i would have expected more of an HD game, using the maximum AA seems to help but not everybody can run that setup without frame rate issues, the frame rate is OK on my case i don't see it dropping or anything noticeable, i think they have done a good job on that regard unlike FF XIII which drops frames like crazy.

Now the story is one of the best on FF, and the music is superb, i recommend this game to anyone who want to try something different in FF.

reviewText:
[GFX: Radeon HD 7870]

Unless you're a supporter of Square-Enix or a huge fan of the game, I don't recommend buying this game at full price. Although it says it's 'HD', at 1080p it still looks like you're playing on a giant stretched out PSP. Game is locked at 30FPS and most of the it's barely even hitting 15FPS. Makes the gameplay very laggy at times. Increasing Anti-Aliasing upscales the resolution, which makes it very laggy if your machine cannot support said resolution. It's not unplayable, but it's very difficult to get used to.  Having said that, the number of options in the graphics menu has increased drastically in comparison to the FFXIII port on release, but that isn't enough to make this a good port. Really hoping that they release an update for this to push the FPS cap, although it's highly unlikely.

The store doesn't specifiy this, but a controller is HIGHLY recommended. I haven't tried it with a keyboard/mouse, but I can't imagine playing this game without a controller.

As far as the game goes, it's actually quite decent. Pretty good storyline, gameplay is active as opposed to turn-based (similar to Crisis Core), but the bad FPS and horrible resolution (even at 1080p) makes the overall experience unenjoyable. Perhaps if you don't mind the bad graphics, you might actually enjoy this game.


Good game, bad port.
Port: 2/10
Game: 8/10

reviewText:
So there's a little disappointment with a few textures and stuff, but in all honesty, if you're playing that much attention to the rug on the floor or the painting on the wall in a game where you're supposed to be doing adventure stuff, your priorities might be a little screwy.

From what I have played, yes, the controls are a little clunky, but every game I've played has been like that from the start. And yes, this game is better played with a controller.

Gameplay is different from any Final Fantasy I have played. Battles aren't menu-driven so much anymore, but are more action/reaction driven. And I have to get acquainted with a large number of playable characters and figure out how to play with them.

It's not bad for a ported game. And while I dislike capped framerates, with the age of the game, if worked just fine on the PSP.

so i bought this game partially on the courier/ward bundle on preorder bonus..but after i played it for a while, it is a very fine jrpg with nice combat mechanics and story..by the old squaresoft final fantasy team..

the graphics looks quite outdated, because it is obviously a port of a psp game..especially on environment textures/3d shapes..but the characters still quite beautiful to look at and movements are fluid on combats..

controls using a controller works like a charm..never tried the key+mouse setup so no complaints on this either..if you're having problem with key+mouse..maybe invest some on a decent controller (im using logitech g710)..you can also use the controller for console type action games such as batman arkham series or shadow of mordor or assasin creed series..it seems more effective to use a controller than a key+mouse for those kind of games..

finally for $20, i think the game is worth the money..thanks for reading

reviewText:
Review [Spoiler Free]
Played the PSP version.  You can find screenshots of it in my profile.
Framerate is capped to 30FPS due to engine limitations.
Uses controller mode.

***Early Impressions***


Story 8.5/10
- Personally one of my favourite FF titles to date
- A much darker tone than any previous Final Fantasy titles.
- Each character has an exaggerated unique personality to differentiate
- You'll be lost/overwhelmed by what's going on in the beginning.  You may need to play the game twice to fully understand
- New Game+ has extra things you can do.  It's not the exact same game over again.

Controls 7/10
- The port allows you to change between three controller schemes
- Camera can be snappy and difficult at time
- Very brief tutorial and controls are shown in menu.  The game isn't too complicated to  learn
- SquareEnix added a snapshot mode and a Fast Forward button for the grindy parts
- When using a controller, the UI interface doesn't switch from keyboard layout -> controller layout automatically.  Must change layout settings in launcher

Graphics 7.5/10
- Game is capped to 30FPS.  You will not be able to change this
- A very lazy graphic port.  If you look in my profile's screenshot folder for the PSP version, they barely redone any textures but the main playable characters, boss character, and academy.
Most of the world textures are ported straight from the PSP version   The redone textures and lighting is super inconsistent with the pre-rendered videos.  What was deveopment team smoking.  The new in-game character models are atrociously glossy and doll-like   To be fair, the redone academy does look pretty sweet.  It's too bad that the game wasn't completely overhauled - Anti-aliasing is pretty misleading.  It's basically downsampling a higher resolution.  Therefore a very high impact to performance (high - highest setting)
I strongly recommend you to read PcGamers' Final Fantasy Type 0 Port Analysis..." for full details on settings and the impact is has on performance - The use of bloom is extremely distracting and unnecessary.  A horrible technique to mask bad textures
- Overall a pretty nasty graphic port.  The combination of oversaturation
hoursPlayed:
and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ texture is almost eye cancer.  The port strayed too far from the original artstyle intended.


Sound 9/10
- The music plays an important role in the game.  It sets the atmosphere and has a special meaning behind it.  I'm glad they stuck with the Japanese version during the dubbing.

- There is dual audio [English/Japanese].


Gameplay 7.5/10
- The gameplay style is a real-time hack-and-slash.  The closest game control-scheme wise that I can relate to is Kingdom Hearts: Birth by Sleep
- It can be grindy at times and you'll always encounter formidable foes or enemies which you must fight against during NG+
- Your AI teammates are pretty derpy.  There's a setting to sub in higher level AI to fight for you to compensate


Weighted Score 8.5/10
My three true elements to a great JRPG is a great story

reviewText: Launch was rough but now that it's running good, I love it.  The story is hard.  You're going to feel pretty bad right away with that poor brave chocobo, and now I'm with the classmates. I used to star with the characters I liked but they will die, and other classmates have to take their place.  I was left by myself fighting the white tiger mech with just the magic pistol girl.  Beating it after 15 tries and almost abondining the mission was very darksouls.  Combat is great I just with they'd bring in the multiplayer

reviewText:
It seems like most of the negative reviews are about the game's failing to be a good HD port, where as the positive reviews praise the game's story, gameplay, etc. My views coincide with the latter rather than the former. I may be more inclined to the former had we seen a stateside release of Agito on PSP, or even mobile, but as this along with the PS4 version are the first that we are seeing the game outside Japan, I really cannot condone the negative reviewers for such a wonderful game that has finally seen the light of day in the west.


So to sum up, great game, love the gameplay, and story.


Side note, if you're having difficulties with the limited res and don't want to manually resize for your PC monitor, then just hdmi out to a TV that suports 720 or 1080.

reviewText: Without a doubt the best version of Type-0. Decent graphical options, solid performance, and nice gameplay additions (such as faster movement speed and camera distance toggles) help the make the game more enjoyable than before. The only downsides are downright bad KB+M controls and a locked framerate-- though again, the performance is solid enough that the latter may not even really be an issue.

reviewText:
I have a HIGH standard when it comes to these games, so Here  go.

In my first play I enjoyed  having to fiddle around with my settings, because my computer thinks that Intel I7 must do everything on here (That is why I got Nvidia, Do not tell her that. This poor laptop will die.) But after about an hour so so of check the forms, I found my fix, and check a couple of other things, set it to max and we are golden.

Well when it come to FF many people think story, characters, gameplay, and Narritve.

But as a long time fan of FF 1, 2, & 3 (Yes those golden boys and girls.) I have had a rather gruel expirence coming up todate on this fish. But After begin drianed by all numbers after 4, I had High hopes for this game. Which are listed as such:

Graphcs are good for a PSP game on a PC

The combat mechanic is Intresting, althouhg I do miss Turn based combat. (Old School Kids.)

The cut scences are nice, but I feel they were nto as good as possible (Reminder I am on a laptop.) So I lose my right to complain by limitations.

The characters depth is very, abrupt. (I feel like am at the petting Zoo.) Their desgins are nice, I like the personalities and everything else so far.

Now for my knit picky butt to start its unconrolled rant.

Its a console remake on to a surpior system, of course there are going be issues so stop complaining.

It was all ready made, just not for Pc. Look We al know that most gaming folk's towers can easily eat thos console's newest game for a snack at still chomp down on these kind of games, but Do be so hung up on this game its been played before its ust for those who want it on their PC.

Not much else for a Pre-order, I feel betrayed by some one, or am Paranoid. Honestly I do not DOTA, and am very picky about my games. As much of a Weeaboo, Otaaku gamer thin I am, I feel like this game has a beutiful side that will get ♥♥♥♥ on later.

Since it is a remake there are going to be bugs, and its going to be a little buggy.

So for The final Verdict, Its great, I do like it, I have never cared for many FF games, Because honestly, Cloud has mental bnreakdowns like he is a hipster, Dream squences are over rated, and happy go lucky charcaters do not become shephroth, and Lighting is like Future Jesus batman?????? I don't know, all I know is that this a recommended game, and I do enjoy its precense, don't get comfy, as soon as Persona 5 comes out your are going right back to HELL FF0HD. Mark MY WORDS. unless you impress me. But really this is a good game. Try it,or steal my Laptop.

reviewText:
Yes it's an action game running at 30FPS, but it plays well enough that it isn't too much of a problem. Controls are smooth and the developers have opted for the relatively simplistic option of deferring antialiasing to supersampling, and at maximum anti-aliasing the game powers through at a downsampled 4k - and doesn't miss a beat on my i7-4790k/OG Titan combo. Textures do look like they have been put through an upscaling filter but they've tried really hard by adding specular mapping and a host of special effects including switchable color correction, screen space shadows, and depth of field effects.

The game feels like a slightly clunkier Kingdom Hearts with a very light sprinkling of Not A Real Sheen Maygoomi Tensay Gaem 3/4 in there with regards to timed conversations, and just the lightest touch of Crisis Core for feels.

Reccomended at a discount price. I got this for £13.34 from GMG.
