reviewText: I waited all day for this to download, having high hopes to finally play a FF title that looked like it might get me back into the series.... then this port shattered that hope into a million crystal pieces. After waiting hours for the DL to complete, I'm greeted with minimal options and am forced into using window mode (gee, thanks), strike one; graphics for the opening cinematic were great, but the sound never, ever managed to synch and there was no options to fix that, save to use subtitles to understand what was going on, so, strike two; strike three is split between the transitional scene between opening cinematic and game play, which was a close up of the characters hands... everything was gloriously detailed, yet his block hands made me feel like I was playing Skyrim with varying graphic mods (this game is an official release, why are the level of graphics so varied?)... once the character stood up and walked away, at first, I thought the slow" walk was for dramatic effect. reviewText: Besides the 30-fps lock and some horrible texturing I don't see much bad with this game so far. Honestly, I don't really care much for the 30-fps lock as I have never lost frames and I give less than a ♥♥♥♥ about texturing. if you play a game only for graphics you're a shallow ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, which sadly describes most gamers today. A lot of people getting into video games these days are hypnotized by flashy and high definition graphics when the only thing that really matters in a good game is gameplay and storytelling ability, which this game has in spades. Also, I play using a keyboard and don't see any problems with the key mapings. You have WASD in place of one joystick and 4568 in stead of another. This may seem awkward at first as you may think, 4568 WTF" but if you have a full keyboard like me you'll see its mapped to the perfect place on the number pad as you can reach the direction keys which take the place of the Dpad. Also if you do end up playing with Keyboard like I do make sure you turn Lock-on to a push/hold instead of a toggle

reviewText:
I've found this port to have a few issues.

Firstly audio and video in pre-rendered cutscenes are not in sync, an issue I overcame using Nvdia Inspector. Secondly there are, bafflingly, only two resolution options (1280x720 and 1920x1080) with no support for resolutions in between. Furthermore there's no .ini file or easy fix I can see for users to implement on their side.

But these are minor issues as the game still functions, albeit in diminished capacity. The major issue is I'm experiencing a game-ending crash a few minutes into the game. No change of drivers of settings changes this. As such I simply can't progress. It's not a case of the port not living up to expectations, but failing to function even as the developers intended. Try as I might I can't progress past this one persistent crash.

I've seen some users unaffected by this on Youtube, so it' not an issue every user will come across, but it does bear mentioning. Do I recommend this game? Not yet.

reviewText:
I've been looking forward to this game since before it ever even came out on psp. I really loved the concept and I loved how it looked. At the time.

Unfortunately, the pc port has some significant issues:

It's extremely unoptimized and can barely hold 30fps on medium settings with AO and camera blur disabled entirely. It usually dips into the 15-20fps range. I have 2x GTX 660ti's in sli. A game that is essentially a psp port with slightly reworked textures and models should not run this badly. I could emulate the original with better results.

I'd complain about the 30fps cap but honestly anyone without a ridiculous build couldn't even run it higher than that in the first place, even on minimal settings. It's disgraceful. An action game like this should definitely support 60fps and be better optimized, especially one that looks as bad as this.

Even worse, it leaves all the graphical settings, which because of the aformentioned optimization issues you'll need to constantly tweak to get a solid framerate, in a pre-game launcher, meaning you can't tweak ANY of these settings in-game. This is outright damning.

Also I'm just disappointed in general at how bad it looks and how long it took to come out in the US, much less on current gen consoles and pc. The original was released on PSP originally in 2011. 4 years and the hd remake still looks like it should've been on PSP.

I'm going to give SE a week to at least announce a patch before refunding this game, but I recommend you wait until it's been fixed to pick it up...

reviewText:
Mediocre port, but good game. A few things you should know on the technical level:

30FPS lock (As mentioned by the Framerate Police)
Resolution option is Output Res ala Dark Souls - Actual resolution is linked to Anti-Aliasing, as goes:

None - 720P
Standard - 1080P
Maximum - 4K

Mouse and Keyboard controls are awful, gamepad is practically mandatory (Glorious WiiU Pro pad here)
Mouse renders on top of the screen at all times, cannot be used in menus, and the mouse controls are blatantly Analog Stick emulation. Worst of all, there is no rebinding keys, just two control-schemes with minimal difference between them.

Now, onto the game itself -

Decent Action-RPG built off of FF7 Crisis Core, with a touch of Monster Hunter. 14 playable characters with different abilities that need to be used in their own ways. There's a world-map with places to explore, for the first time in an FF game since the PS1 FF games.

Prepare to die a lot, it's somewhat difficulty, especially since your party members have barely any health. Running is advised if enemies 5+ levels higher are encountered.

Also, RTS elements as well, quite interesting departure from where the series has gone before IMO - Though I recall something similar in the SNES FF games.

All in all a good experience if you can look past the issues of the port.

reviewText:
Now that I have actually BEATEN the game, I think I can give a truly complete review:

Slightly different from its predacessors, Type 0 plays more like an Action RPG closer to Kingdom Hearts and the like. You can customize your actions, abilties, spells and equipment. Furthermore, you get all of your team members at the beginning of the game and to play at your leisure/play style (all of which have unique combat styles and tactics they use to fight/support in battle) It takes on a darker setting of a world at war with itself, without leaving out the horrors that come with it. That's your basic premise.

Now lets talk more about the aspects of the game itself. It has both keyboard and controller (360) interface (which I feel handles better than the PSP version). Very minimal resolution settings for windowed mode selecting from 1920x1080 and 1280x720, most of the commands you can't edit either. Normally I wouldn't have a problem with this as they're very natural for the most part... however there's a speed up button bound to the L3 button, which I keep bumping into during intense combat, making it even more awkward to control at times (this experience might be just myself, but if I could edit it, it wouldn't be an issue is all I'm getting at)

While I found the combat to be very enjoyable and varied, I found the enemy variety to be somewhat lacking once you get about 3 chapters into the game. Dodging is a very important mechanic to the point you are generally better off trying to spam rolls over any defensive countermeasure like Protect  or the like. And you WILL die a LOT in this game, not necessarily fail a mission, but HP is for the most part arbitrary as you'll find on Officer difficulty and above, most enemies possess the ability to take you down in just a few attacks (having you tag team in another party member to keep fighting). Fortunately, there are SOME countermeasures to the consistent dying, but are very VERY situational to the point without another human player to execute them, they won't work very often (which was how the PSP version was designed), which brings me to another issue: The AI. You're going to be tearing your hair out a lot on the AI's lack of discretion and general skill/situational awareness, as expected its an AI. But when you lose a potential tagout as a result of their poor decision making, it can be very frustrating on harder missions (of which, I would often just solo one character through and tag out as I went along) The AI understands basic tactics like using cure when you're below a certain HP threshold, but will actually attempt to engage certain high level" enemies indiscriminently (you will know what I'm talking about once you're up to about chapter 3)

I didn't care for the overworld layout much either
date: most of the land in the game never actually can be explored until very late game
recommended: and even then spawns lvl 99 monsters in the process. There's a FEW caves you can explore but the rest is intended for VERY high level characters which I'll touch base on in a minute

reviewText:
Even though i do enjoy the game, i would be lying if i saying this is a good remastered PC Port:

- The framerate locked at 30fps (good enough for me)
- The first time i start this game, it ran at 10fps making me had to quit and start again to get a stable 30fps
- The graphics is fine for last generation console but some parts have really bad textures (like the dead guy bleeding gelatin blood in the first cutscene <<<< The WItcher 3 blood). They remastered most character models and  buildings but there are some interiors and  objects look very PS2-ish.
- The cutscenes are strangely disjointed. Some cutscenes look like have been remastered to HD and have brighter color while some cutscenes look like they are carry straight from the PSP version to PC (green template, low resolution,..)
- The combat is surprisingly fast (a lot faster than i expected it to be) with very odd controls, short  and unhelpful tutorial. I cannot speak for the rest of the game but during my first hour playthrough, i mostly just smash button and do some quick dodging.
- The lock on system is dreadful (who ever designed this lock on system must be high on meth). The camera snaps haphazardly when i try to do quick movement or attack.  I have to lock on everytime or you will occasionally miss targets that stand like 2 ft in front of me.
- The animation is awful ( jerky and stiff). They look like animations that meant to be placeholder for other game Alpha testing.
- Typical anime characters and story (i like it personally because i love anime)
- Missing voice acting in some case. No interactions with NPC
- This game is loading screen heaven. Everytime you enter an area, there is a loading screen. I go to the elevator that is right in front of me but still have to go through a loading screen


THis game is only for die hard fan of Final Fantasy series. If you are new to the series or expecting spectacular first tast of the FF series, i suggest you play other game and wait for this game to go on sale for at least 50% off

reviewText:
[This is a Day 1 review so results may very]

To be honest with you, I've seen worse ports *cough* Dark Souls *cough*

Even on the day of release, Final Fantasy Type-0 HD is recieving a lot of negative reviews, due to its bad port and problems that people are coming across.


- Has only 2 resolution 1920x1080 and 1280x720.
- Fullscreen make the textures look more disgusting so you have to play this game on Windows
- Camera control is awful, especially when changing targets.
- Control are all over the place on the keyboard and can be rather confusing at first. (It is recommended that you play this game with a controller)
- FPS is lock on 30 FPS (Not really a problem to some people but it's still an issue)
- Textures in general are either really low-res or below average.

The game isn't bad, it's actually pretty fun but the port is what makes me not recommend it. In the current state that the game is in, I wouldn't recommend this game but who knows, it's the day of release for this game so updates are bound to come.
voteText: 7 of 21 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This port is a ♥♥♥♥ing abortion. Seriously, the idea that they thought this was okay to release to the public and sell is beyond insulting.

FULL CONTROLLER SUPPORT is a lie. I couldn't get a single controller working with it, even after ♥♥♥♥ing with x360ce and searching everywhere for a solution. There is absolutely no information online, most likely because the port just got released.

UPGRADED GRAPHICS RESOLUTION OPTIONS FOR HIGH END PCs is a lie. There are literally two resolution options: 1280x720 and 1920x1080.

Speaking of graphics, it doesn't even look like they bothered to update the textures from the PSP version. So if you want to play a game that looks like it got upscaled from 480x272 to 1920x1080, be my guest. Also, the game clock is locked to 30 FPS, and if you manage to find a way to force unlock the framerate, the entire game will speed up and become unplayable as a result.

Do not buy this port. It is not just awful, it is deceitful. Half of the feature list for the PC version of this game ranges from misleading to blatantly dishonest. Save your money.

reviewText:
The game is perfectly fine. If you are looking for a decent RPG with a more mature story than other FF games, this game is for you.

Said that, this is not the way to release a game on PC. Just like FFXIII or XIII-2, SE is not learning from his mistakes. You CAN'T release a game on PC with frame rate cap at 30. You can't release a game on PC with performance problems. You can't release a game on PC with the HD on it's game and have lower texture quality than a 15 year old game.

Keep away unless you can cope with the fact that this is a PSP ported for consoles/PC.

reviewText:
One of the best Final Fantasy games ever!!

Pros:
- 14 playable characters. Each characters have their own play style.
- Great story.
- Badass l'Cie, unlike FFXIII l'Cie.
- Very fast paced battle system.
- AWESOME soundtracks. This or FFXIII-2 soundtracks is the best of the series.
- Oldschool world map.
- Chocobo riding, capturing, breeding.
- Controllable airship.
- Gilgamesh.
- Emina's lingerie scenes.
- FFVI + FFVIII + Harry Potter = This game.

Cons:
- Low-res textures.
- NPCs look very bad.
- Unable to customize buttons.
- Only support X360 controller.

reviewText:
So far so....bad, sadly

The camera is awful, you're on a fight and most of the time you don't even know where the enemies are, to the point that I feel ashamed of myself to DIE on the tutorial.

Full screen -> Your monitor does not support that resolution. Ok then, windowed it i....WTF IS THIS, RESIZE the INSIDE of the window? Nevermind....

And the graphics, oh the graphics. I know, graphics aren't everything.... it doesn't matter.... Well, let me tell you, on an AAA game such as Final Fantasy (and taking XIII as some way of reference), and focusing on theee performance this thing has on a mediocre PC.... No, this is ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as hell. If you can't hold 30 fps using that BS every-single-thing-you-look-at, ffs square, this game could've been great let's say.... 10 years ago.

TL;DR

Don't, just don't. ♥♥♥♥♥♥ camera, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ options, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ graphics, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ performance.

reviewText:
Probably a good game but I can't condone this ♥♥♥♥. REFUND INBOUND!

The stoy seems engaging at first, the opening cut scenes were good enough to inoke feels, from what I've heard it continues in a similar tone, could be worth playing for the story, however there's far too many repeated SINS committed by SE once again following on from their other recent ports to PC.

Remastered textures look quite good, in some cases the gameplay looks better than the cutscenes... however turn a corner and its like a bird ♥♥♥♥ on your screen.
Perhaps the only plus is the option to reduce, even remove the motion blur that spoilt the console versions.
30 fps was expected and not a huge problem, it will always be considered a negative. Resolution choice of 720 or 1080... no good for anyone on a ultrawide or higher res screen.

Combat, for me wasnt great, didnt feel smooth or fluid, seemed very limited to spam attack to win, can't draw proper judgement as I hardly progessed through the game before it lost my interest. However, definetely offers up eye candy with some of the visuals.


A good chunk could be resolved with a patch (maybe 6mo. later) Gedosato won't save it this time, believe it only supports DX9 and this is a DX11 game.

reviewText:
Officially the worst game game in the history of Final Fantasy games.
If you are a true fan of the Final Fantasy series, stay far away from this, don't even poke it with a stick.
I regret trying this at all. There's absolutely nothing Final Fantasy about it.
Now I know for certain that there's absolutely no hope that Square Enix will ever release a real or good Final Fantasy game at all.
(All the good Final Fantasy games were released by Squaresoft.)

Nevermind the textures or FPS lock or performance issues.
The story, the characters, the combat system and even the gameplay is just a nightmare come true.
The main characters are all named after cards, and the combat system is made out of throwing magic cards at opponents..........
The first thing they do in the story is kill a Chocobo!
It's as if Hitler him self took over making Final Fantasy.

This is just too depressing. My beloved Final Fantasy is truly and utterly dead!
All they are doing now is repeatedly selling us rotting corpses.
